0.12.text:
I enjoy photographing people that give me
a reason to lift my camera. I think it’s

5.36.text:
very different and very difficult when there’s
very little visual interest.

10.25.text:
I tend not to spend very much time with the
sitter beforehand and I let them, through

16.88.text:
my assistants or PA, decide if they want hair
or make up or what’s at their disposal,

23.10.text:
depending on what it is.
I usually stay away at that point and when

26.57.text:
I meet them it's when they sit down or stand
up in front of the camera, and I let it go

31.93.text:
from there.
I try and let things orchestrate themselves

35.79.text:
in a way. I’ve always chosen some lighting
that I think is appropriate or the way that

41.82.text:
I want to see that person but I’m often
wrong I often start shooting and realise quite

48.49.text:
quickly.
I shoot a few frames and then I go look at

51.16.text:
the screen which is always turned away from
the sitter, sometimes I include it especially

56.96.text:
if people are actors because they can bring
a lot, they are equal to me in the collaboration

62.98.text:
I feel. But with people that are nervous I
certainly turn the screen away. I have a different

69.00.text:
are of the studio that I go and have a look
and very often I decide that what I thought

78.07.text:
would be appropriate really isn’t and then
I rethink it. That’s when it gets interesting

85.17.text:
really when you start changing it and reacting
to who a person is or how they are and how

92.36.text:
you can show it….. it’s not a real cerebral
thing for me and therefore very difficult

98.91.text:
to put into words. In a way I’m quite scared
of really actually finding out how I work

106.72.text:
because I’m not sure if it’ll be as edgy
anymore… but I do use light to reveal or

116.71.text:
the opposite of reveal with my subjects how
they are feeling or how I feel. I think there

123.66.text:
is a lot of correspondence and communication
between two human beings that goes on without

131.69.text:
ones mouth moving and that’s in body language
and I think in just brain waves, I think we

137.43.text:
do really connect and its often quite a heightened
moment for the sitter because they have somebody

146.91.text:
quite near them with a camera pointing at
them and it’s in those heightened moments

152.27.text:
you communicate even better and I think something
like that goes on and I really trust in it

157.69.text:
and that’s what I trust, and it’s that
moment when a picture becomes a portrait.

163.18.text:
I really deal with the cadaver of a person
it’s a form in front of me that I show in

168.78.text:
a certain way by lighting in a certain way.
I’m certainly not looking for a truth in

173.51.text:
them. Often I think it might be more a truth
in me. I might move a light because I want

179.91.text:
to reveal something more about a person or
to make it feel a bit more sinister by moving

185.02.text:
a light back and that’s really how I work
I’m not trying to talk to them and as they

193.84.text:
move a hand catch something or as they rub
their head I think that when I’ve done that

198.62.text:
in the past its been because there was nothing
else, it’s a last resort really. I far prefer

206.47.text:
to settle people and try to get more of a
rich emotion. I like to know how they look

217.26.text:
so I recognise who’s who when they walk
in the door, but really not more than that.

224.30.text:
I like the connection human beings have when
there isn’t a great knowledge like when

232.38.text:
you first meet people. I would find it very
hard to photograph a friend well or to photograph

237.56.text:
somebody that I knew well. I think that that
tension when you first meet people allows

243.04.text:
you to communicate without speaking really
sharply. So no, I don’t find out a lot,

252.47.text:
I don’t chat a lot, I hardly talk when I
photograph but there will be something about

258.30.text:
a person that will cause me to direct them
following things they do, they might glance

265.55.text:
somewhere and it makes me think something
that I trust and try something with them and

270.28.text:
slowly they become themselves, they're very
accurately themselves and that’s when I

276.74.text:
think it works the best.
When I first received the commission I was

283.90.text:
obviously really really proud to work once
again with the National Portrait Gallery.

288.86.text:
It really means a lot having grown up in South
Africa and now having been here thirty years

292.71.text:
it really feels like my national gallery,
and I’m really proud.

299.52.text:
I immediately realised that these might be
people, the 'Rising Stars' part of the commission

307.02.text:
might be people who are incredibly famous
for their sport in years to come, so there’s

315.65.text:
quite a lot of responsibility to do something
that matters.

321.74.text:
First of all I thought of them being black
and white and I’m not sure why, I often

326.65.text:
work in this way where I let things come into
my consciousness and I feel them out and I

333.91.text:
think about them and see how they fit. Black
and white seemed to have an iconic status

342.61.text:
for me especially when it comes to sport,
probably because of the influence of Leni

348.18.text:
Riefenstahl in my life when I was eighteen
or so. I think I discovered her work and the

352.39.text:
film she did of the Olympics in 1936 so that
was probably the reason, but equally I didn’t

359.14.text:
want to do work like that that instantly would
look very dated, very iconic in that proletarian

367.42.text:
or German way. I wanted to do something that
was modern but still rooted, really rooted

375.57.text:
in photography. So black and white came up,
I looked through a lot of the portraits I

381.68.text:
had done before looking for a fit for what
might work for four different people and came

388.38.text:
up with this way of lighting that’s really
quite contrasty, slightly revealing but not

395.31.text:
really, most of the picture is in shadow,
I always think you can tell so much more about

400.54.text:
yourself and why you react to the picture
in the same way as people… a good example

405.17.text:
would be how people react to a Francis Bacon.
There’s very little information on the canvas

410.54.text:
yet you have a strong reaction. Or Rothko,
maybe even that’s better, as there’s almost

414.82.text:
nothing on the canvas, a lot of paint, but
very little information and yet you react

420.18.text:
in such a strong way, or some people do. It’s
taken me a while to workit out, but it’s

428.53.text:
that kind of shrouding and a way of showing
shadow that's very compelling to me.

435.33.text:
I always think about the viewer even more
than I do about the sitter, I think when you’re

440.87.text:
working in this domain it’s all about the
visitors reacting to a photograph. So it becomes

445.98.text:
a triangle; you have your sitter, you have
your photographer or artist and you have the

450.54.text:
viewer, and that viewer is really really important.
With the National Portrait Gallery, unlike

456.53.text:
say White Cube or Gagosian or the Met or the
Tate you are possibly not going to see art,

464.43.text:
but to receive information. The pictures need
to be really accessible to a wide audience

469.75.text:
and I think lit the way they are, quite beautifully
photographed seemed to make a lot of sense

476.82.text:
to me.
I think at about eleven or twelve years old

482.19.text:
I started taking pictures and found that I
was quite good at them and I think it was

487.38.text:
probably the only thing I felt good about.
Schooling was a total failure for me, I found

493.22.text:
it very difficult more than a failure. I think
I always wanted to excel at something and

500.35.text:
I loved the mechanics of cameras and taking
pictures and the results that I seemed to

508.83.text:
get. So that’s how I got into it. By thirteen
I had my own camera and then I went off, I

513.77.text:
went into motorbikes for quite a while then
had a really bad accident and by eighteen

518.82.text:
I was positive that that that's what my life
would be.

524.43.text:
Growing up in South Africa, there wasn’t
TV until I was fifteen and certainly not internet

531.33.text:
so I had a few books and in a way I think
it was a really great way to be introduced,

537.13.text:
because what you saw you really delved into.
Now there’s so much that I’m not sure

542.70.text:
what people take out of it or how they get
influenced, but I was very influenced by Edward

546.81.text:
Weston and I think in many ways people know
my work now as being so varied, although there’s

557.33.text:
a very strong strand of me in it, and there’s
always a slightly uncomfortable feeling in

561.70.text:
my work, a way I don’t want to airbrush
one's dark side away let’s say… it's very

572.36.text:
much in Edward Weston’s work too. He would
photograph a rusty car on the same day as

576.66.text:
a nude and a week later a cloud and when you
look at them in a book, that cloud and that

582.50.text:
nude are exactly the same and that rusty car’s
not that different either and I loved that,

588.70.text:
I didn’t see it as oh these are three different
things, I just thought this is photography

595.68.text:
and such a tight expression of who he was
and I’ve always followed that path.

601.97.text:
I’ve printed every photograph that I ever
took almost without exception, every single

606.82.text:
black and white and colour picture that I've
ever taken. When the computer slowly came

613.08.text:
into my life, at first I would come from the
dark room with a print which I would then

618.07.text:
scan in and then make a small adjustment,
then soon after I’d be scanning the neg

625.19.text:
in, but still doing a great print and making
my neg look like my print. And then I would

631.48.text:
just print one to see what I wanted, still
have the dark room experience, but come into

635.83.text:
the computer and finish it and do most of
my work by scanning from the neg, until I

642.85.text:
wasn’t walking into the dark room. That
probably took a year and a half, what I've

647.05.text:
just described. How I work on a computer now
is very similar to how I worked in the dark

651.52.text:
room, where I try a certain colour range,
see how I respond to it and what I want to

659.34.text:
do to it and I make changes and changes like
I used to make print after print, and then

664.63.text:
I compare them all and see the direction I
want to go. The only real difference for me

670.47.text:
is that you can be far more accurate on a
computer, you can really be more accurate

674.06.text:
if you want to, which I often choose not to
be, I often choose to change whole areas rather

679.09.text:
than accurate areas. So I really see it as
quite smooth and very important and very similar.

687.78.text:
The outputting of course is excellent now,
as I most of the time do with colour work

695.67.text:
and do lambda prints, it’s photographic
material, it’s still a wet process, there

700.10.text:
are no spots. The main problem with my older
work is wherever you spot an odd colour, it

705.60.text:
goes red after ten years. I think it’s a
far better way. Black and white is possibly

713.45.text:
different, there were so many mistakes you
might do in black and white that would add

719.30.text:
layering to a print which is not possible
when you have to decide what you are going

723.40.text:
to do, which is the difference with a computer.
I think what is different though with digital

728.81.text:
work is the taking; to photograph digitally
rather than photographing on film is much

738.54.text:
more of a question. With film you tend to
stay nervous longer and never be sure what

745.76.text:
you have and maybe try things you would never
try. In comparison, with digital, as soon

752.25.text:
as you can see on the screen that things are
really working or that you have a fantastic

756.64.text:
shot, you cannot keep that edge anymore, your
nervousness leaves you and once it has left

763.19.text:
you… I don’t think I’ve ever produced
as well as that picture. When the nervousness

768.69.text:
did leave me you go round in circles, but
it’s never the same. I think there's real

776.79.text:
arguments, if you shoot digitally, to throw
that screen out the window and just try and

783.70.text:
make it like film.
The joy I originally had with cameras and

789.62.text:
those beautifully made things that you would
turn and click has really all gone; I have

794.40.text:
no love for the actual thing that I hold anymore
when I do portraiture which I certainly used

798.95.text:
to with the Hasselblads or my Lindoffs. I
would have been happier if it was still the

803.58.text:
way it was. I was very competent in the dark
room… I don’t mind, I’m just using what’s
